description:
Dromiciops gliroides, commonly known as the monito del monte, is a small marsupial native to the temperate rainforests of southern Chile and western Argentina. It belongs to the order Paucituberculata, which is a group of small, mouse-like marsupials.

The monito del monte is a nocturnal and arboreal species, living primarily in the canopy of the forests. It has a rounded body, large eyes, and a long, prehensile tail that it uses for climbing and balance. The fur is typically grayish-brown in color, and the animal has a distinctive white spot on its chest.

Dromiciops gliroides is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of small invertebrates, fruits, and even small vertebrates. It plays an important role in the ecosystem, acting as a seed disperser and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the temperate rainforests.

Interestingly, the monito del monte is considered a living fossil, as it is the only surviving member of the order Paucituberculata in the modern era. It is an important species for evolutionary studies, as it provides insights into the early diversification and adaptations of marsupial mammals.
